**
 http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/08/070807145140.htm

 
 Not a good week on the hominid front for Darwinists. First the homo habilis thing, now this (from your link):
 
 "This feature implies some level of Neanderthal ancestry in this otherwise modern human fossil," the authors explain
 
 Of course, this is not surprising since Neanderthal DNA is 99.9% the same as ours:
 
 http://www.unexplained-mysteries.com/viewnews.php?id=82519
 
 Human/Neanderthal DNA 99.9% identical
 
 
 Of course the problem here, is there is not enough time to go from Neanderthal morphology to "modern" morphology by way of RMNS. This is why science needs the Neanderthals be a different species and to go extinct, leaving no trace behind. But if modern humans descended from Neanderthals, darwinists will have to admit that the transformation happened nearly instantly.

Of course the problem here, is there is not enough time to go from Neanderthal morphology to "modern" morphology by way of RMNS. This is why science needs the Neanderthals be a different species and to go extinct, leaving no trace behind. But if modern humans descended from Neanderthals, darwinists will have to admit that the transformation happened nearly instantly.

 
 Please provide the actual estimates of the time required along with the necessary references if you please! How much time WOULD it take with confidence limits please!

I don't see any reason why any of that is a bad week for science. Both sets of findings are new information, and that alone is a net advance.
 
 It is true that the significance of the African discoveries have been misrepresented, apparently stemming from the original scientific reports, so that's an embarrassment, but otherwise it's all interesting stuff that improves our knowledge, which is a great thing.
 
 The co-occurence of a late surviving Homo habilis and a Homo erectus says nothing for or against direct evolutionary relationships between them except that if the one gave rise to the other it was not by complete anagenic change. If a sub-group splits off and speciates, nothing, NOTHING, requires the parent group to go extinct. Your parents didn't have to die when you were born, and species can operate the same way. It is also interesting that apparently the two species apparently differed enough in their niches so as not to overlap too significantly.
 
 Whether or not H. habilis was the direct ancestor of H. erectus or was instead a cousin doesn't matter hugely to the evolutionary interpretation of the origin of modern humans. We are clearly primates; H. erectus and H. habilis clearly represent extinct hominids that are like us in many important ways; and there have clearly been a whole host of habilis / erectus / etc. like species in the past, out of one of which we appear to have evolved. Note that it is a great mistake to consider that ancient hominids only lived where we have fossils of them. Relevant fossils are still limited to only a very few times and places, so it is inevitable that there is more to learn about our ancestors and close relatives. 
 
 
This is why science needs the Neanderthals be a different species and to go extinct
 You are on some different planet there. Science doesn't need one conclusion or the other. The traditional classification of neandertals has been Homo sapiens neanderthalensis, i.e., in the same species. Then genetic work suggested that neandertals were distinct enough to merit being a separate species [Hodges, S. B., 2000, Human Evolution: A start for population genomics. Nature (7 Dec. 2000): 408(6813):652-653.]. Results since then have been mixed. Some DNA work indicates a 5% admixture from Neandertals (Plagnol V, Wall JD, 2006, Possible ancestral structure in human populations. PLoS Genetics @ http://genetics.plosjournals.org/perlserv/?request=get-document&doi=10.1371/journal.pgen.0020105.eor&ct=1 ). Various fossils continue to suggest some interbreeding. (Note also that a genetic finding of no interbreeding does not conflict with fossilized hybrids - it merely says that any hybrids or hybrid lines ended up dying out before they contributed to any lineages that were successful all the way to the present.)
 
 A finding of 99.5 to 99.9% genetic similarity is what we expect, given the clear similarity of the two groups.
 
 
there is not enough time to go from Neanderthal morphology to "modern" morphology by way of RMNS
 First, evolution change includes more mechanisms than M&NS alone. Secondly, as Chemist said, if you are so sure that there isn't enough time, perhaps you could tell us just exactly how much time would be needed to undergo a change of 0.001, and how long ago exactly the neandertal / H. sapiens sapiens split happened, in order to prove your point.

You are on some different planet there. Science doesn't need one conclusion or the other here. The traditional classification of neandertals has been Homo sapiens neanderthalensis, i.e., in the same species. Then genetic work suggested that neandertals were distinct enough to merit being a separate species [Hodges, S. B., 2000, Human Evolution: A start for population genomics. Nature (7 Dec. 2000): 408(6813):652-653.]. Results since then have been mixed. Some DNA work indicates a 5% admixture from Neandertals (Plagnol V, Wall JD, 2006, Possible ancestral structure in human populations. PLoS Genetics @ http://genetics.plosjournals.org/per...20105.eor&ct=1 ). Various fossils continue to suggest some interbreeding. (Note also that a genetic finding of no interbreeding does no conflict with fossilized hybrids - it merely says that any hybrids or hybrid lines ended up dying out before they contributed to any lineages that were successful all the way to the present.

 
 Indeed he is. Good analysis there. The question of whether N was our ancestor or just a cousin has long been under study. At times as you point out it was thought to be ancestral at others not. At no time was any of this seen to have an impact on evolutionary theory as such, nor was there any reason for it to do so. Its a question of the evolution of a specific species (ie ourselves and N) and not a question of evolutionary theory.
 
 As to modern Ns consider that they seem to have established themselves as spokesmen for a well known insurance company in modern times. They are quite intelligent and fast on their feet, but they seem never to have invented grooming. Its probably genetic. I also have observed what appear at first glance to be hybrids on a bus I used to take to work.

And to quote from the OP:
 
 
 
"This feature implies some level of Neanderthal ancestry in this otherwise modern human fossil," the authors explain. "It joins other early modern European fossils, from the sites of Oase and Muierii in Romania, Mlasdec in the Czech Republic, and Les Rois in France in indicating some degree of Neanderthal admixture occurred when modern humans spread across Europe starting around 40,000 years ago."

 
 In other words none of this is particulary new - its just another example of a possible H&N hybrid. Not beyond the pale and not impacting on TOE.

Not beyond the pale and not impacting on TOE.

 But nonetheless fascinating!

But nonetheless fascinating!

 
 Yes indeed, the possibility of there being more than one large brained ape like species and there being genetic exchange between the two is fascinating indeed. Even knowing we had cousins (if not kissing cousins) is fascinating. In fact the whole story falls under that banner! emoticon_xhoho

I don't see any reason why any of that is a bad week for science. Both sets of findings are new information, and that alone is a net advance.
 
 It is true that the significance of the African discoveries have been misrepresented, apparently stemming from the original scientific reports, so that's an embarrassment, but otherwise it's all interesting stuff that improves our knowledge, which is a great thing.
 
 The co-occurence of a late surviving Homo habilis and a Homo erectus says nothing for or against direct evolutionary relationships between them except that if the one gave rise to the other it was not by complete anagenic change. If a sub-group splits off and speciates, nothing, NOTHING, requires the parent group to go extinct. Your parents didn't have to die when you were born, and species can operate the same way. It is also interesting that apparently the two species apparently differed enough in their niches so as not to overlap too significantly.
 
 Whether or not H. habilis was the direct ancestor of H. erectus or was instead a cousin doesn't matter hugely to the evolutionary interpretation of the origin of modern humans. We are clearly primates; H. erectus and H. habilis clearly represent extinct hominids that are like us in many important ways; and there have clearly been a whole host of habilis / erectus / etc. like species in the past, out of one of which we appear to have evolved. Note that it is a great mistake to consider that ancient hominids only lived where we have fossils of them. Relevant fossils are still limited to only a very few times and places, so it is inevitable that there is more to learn about our ancestors and close relatives. 
 
 You are on some different planet there. Science doesn't need one conclusion or the other. The traditional classification of neandertals has been Homo sapiens neanderthalensis, i.e., in the same species. Then genetic work suggested that neandertals were distinct enough to merit being a separate species [Hodges, S. B., 2000, Human Evolution: A start for population genomics. Nature (7 Dec. 2000): 408(6813):652-653.]. Results since then have been mixed. Some DNA work indicates a 5% admixture from Neandertals (Plagnol V, Wall JD, 2006, Possible ancestral structure in human populations. PLoS Genetics @ http://genetics.plosjournals.org/perlserv/?request=get-document&doi=10.1371/journal.pgen.0020105.eor&ct=1 ). Various fossils continue to suggest some interbreeding. (Note also that a genetic finding of no interbreeding does not conflict with fossilized hybrids - it merely says that any hybrids or hybrid lines ended up dying out before they contributed to any lineages that were successful all the way to the present.)
 
 A finding of 99.5 to 99.9% genetic similarity is what we expect, given the clear similarity of the two groups.
 
 First, evolution change includes more mechanisms than M&NS alone. Secondly, as Chemist said, if you are so sure that there isn't enough time, perhaps you could tell us just exactly how much time would be needed to undergo a change of 0.001, and how long ago exactly the neandertal / H. sapiens sapiens split happened, in order to prove your point.

 
 N. Wells...if the Neanderthal morphology changed into modern human morphology quickly, then that means non-evolutionary mechanisms were responsible. Just as an example, infant's bones are very soft and shapeable.....if the Neanderthals were indeed early humans and thus long-lived (as stated in the Bible) then we can possibly assume that they matured at later times. Kids nowdays are starting to mature earlier and earlier. But if this trend is extrapolated backwards in time thousands of years, we can assume that maybe instead of puberty happening between the ages of 12-14, it may have happened between the ages of 18-25...(just a guess). If this were the case, the Neanderthals' would have grown at a slower rate and their bones would have been soft and shapeable for longer periods of time. Given this, if these people were to have eaten a diet heavy in meat, this might have given them their heavy brows over their eyes...(used as resistance in chewing). However, as agriculture was introduced and diets changed..(leaning more towards breads and grains) not only might it have effected lifespan, but also morphology. 
 
 The idea that diet can change morphology, specifically skull shape, is not new. There is also a trend in the human race for smaller, more rounded heads.
 
 http://english.people.com.cn/200608/17/eng20060817_294183.html
 
 Dr. Wu Xue Jie from the IVPP said experts in the research team tested, analyzed and compared 718 skulls belonging to Chinese adult males who lived during the New Stone Age, the Bronze Age and modern times. They discovered that Chinese people's craniums and viscerocraniums are getting smaller; their noses and eye sockets are becoming narrower; and their skulls are becoming more rounded. 
 
 I can also show you how a diet high in sugar and starches causes the brain to shrink and alter skull shape in other various ways.
 
 Evolutionists, however, say that morpholgy changed because of random mutations and natural selection. But like I said before, there is not enough time represented in the fossil record for RMNS to take place...(not to mention no real reason why these physical changes would make them better breeders.) This is why Neanderthals have been called a different species and have been killed off without giving rise to modern humans.
 
 doubt me that they're called a different species?
 
 http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/3431609.stm
 
 The Neanderthals were not close relatives of modern humans and represent a single species quite distinct from our own, scientists say
 
 Yet you say they are the same species. Yet no one actually knows what a "species" is -- so it's all a big joke anyway.
 
 But the point is, if modern day humans really did descend from Neanderthals by experiencing just a simple change in morphology by way of environmental influences, it pretty much destroys the concept of human evolution. Homo erectus, the supposed ancestor to Neanderthals is shaped much like them -- so much like them that they've been called "little Neanderthals." So Neanderthals and homo erectus are basically one in the same -- just different sized bodies and located in different parts of the world. The problem is, though, there is no "evolution" between them, and there is no "evolution" between them and us. We are all humans -- and there is no bridge -- including homo habilis -- to any other creature on earth.
 
 Not only that, but the kicker is, the timeline for morphological change must be shrunk to the extreme. We can assume, if the changes stemmed from environmental influences, that change took place not over hundreds of thousands of years, but over just a few generations. Oops....the concept of evolution is all starting to fall apart.
 
 There's a very good reason Neanderthals were said to have died off without giving rise to modern humans -- because the alternative kills ToE.

N. Wells...if the Neanderthal morphology changed into modern human morphology quickly, then that means non-evolutionary mechanisms were responsible.

 
 Well all you have to do is tell us the minimum time during which it could happen by NDS theory and then how long it actually took and we can compare the numbers. Of course you will have to detail how you arrived at both sets of numbers. Enjoy emoticon_xangel

Well all you have to do is tell us the minimum time during which it could happen by NDS theory and then how long it actually took and we can compare the numbers. Of course you will have to detail how you arrived at both sets of numbers. Enjoy emoticon_xangel

 
 why is that my job? I'm sure the info is out there. I don't know the specifics of how many thousands of years (or generations) it would take in a darwinian fairytale. I'm sure they stuck a molecular clock on it. What does it matter anyway? Do you deny that non-evolutionary mechanisms working in individuals would happen in the blink of an eye compared to RMNS working on a population spread out over thousands of miles?

why is that my job? I'm sure the info is out there. I don't know the specifics of how many thousands of years (or generations) it would take in a darwinian fairytale. I'm sure they stuck a molecular clock on it. What does it matter anyway? Do you deny that non-evolutionary mechanisms working in individuals would happen in the blink of an eye compared to RMNS working on a population spread out over thousands of miles?

 
 
 Because you made the claim of knowing that the time available was too short to allow for evolution to do the job. If you know then you must have a basis for knowing and obviously you should be capable of telling us the details of that basis. If not then you are probably just blowing smoke.

From SS 
doubt me that they're called a different species?
 
 http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/3431609.stm
 
 The Neanderthals were not close relatives of modern humans and represent a single species quite distinct from our own, scientists say
 
 Yet you say they are the same species. 

 
 Please re-read both what I said, and what your cited article says. I'm not doubting that some people have called them a different species. I said that their classification is controversial and has gone both ways, from the same species arguable to different species (but should probably go back to being the same species). The article that you cite takes pains to make the same point, contrary to what you imply by selective quoting. The rest of the article says things like:
 
 Others claim Neanderthals contributed significantly to the modern gene pool.
 
 ........ 
 
 But Dr Ahern added that, while the Neanderthal specimens used in the study are all male, several of the early modern Europeans the authors compare them with are female skulls.
 
 .......
 
 But some researchers believe this does not exclude the possibility that interbreeding occurred. Dr Magnus Nordborg, of Lund University in Sweden, has calculated that even if Neanderthals had comprised 25% of the population after merging with modern humans, their DNA might be impossible to detect today. 

 
 
 
 There's a very good reason Neanderthals were said to have died off without giving rise to modern humans -- because the alternative kills ToE. 

 Whether neandertals are a 'breed apart' or not is of great interest, but the ToE is perfectly comfortable whichever way the facts turn out. Your claim is beyond stupid - if, as you say, "science needs the Neanderthals be a different species", how come so many evolutionary biologists held to the opposite conclusion for so long? This is not an area where the ToE predicts or needs a specific outcome.
 
 
 I can also show you how a diet high in sugar and starches causes the brain to shrink and alter skull shape in other various ways.
 Biologists have never disputed that phenotype reflects more than just genotype alone (if you've had nose surgery, you've altered your phenotype), although note that the changes you mention are neither genetic nor heritable, so they are not evolutionary. 
 
 You continue to state, without evidence, that there is insufficient time for the changes to happen. A weight increase of 0.1% per generation could take a mouse-size creature to an elephant-size creature in 60,000 years. Compared to that, biologists have measured size changes of various body parts as high as 5-10% in a single generation (e.g., Grant with Geospiza). There are a lot of reasons why such a change is unlikely to happen so quickly over the long term, but it is sufficent to question your claim of insufficient time. Also, a small change in a regulatory gene can immediately have many diverse effects: look up what can happen during environmentally-induced neoteny, for instance, as an example of what could happen during neoteny induced by genetic mutations.

Because you made the claim of knowing that the time available was too short to allow for evolution to do the job. If you know then you must have a basis for knowing and obviously you should be capable of telling us the details of that basis. If not then you are probably just blowing smoke.

 
 
 
 Excellent points and unavoidable logic.
 
 I suspect that Sport will either:
 
 1. Abandon the thread
 2. Make a series of "challenges"
 3. Attempt to shift the burden of proof (again)
 4. link to and/or quote some internet press release
 5. Various combinations of the above

I can also show you how a diet high in sugar and starches causes the brain to shrink and alter skull shape in other various ways.

 
 OK. Do it.

OK. Do it.

 
 One wonders if he is referring to himself as a demonstration of such an unfortunate dimunition of capacity!

 1. Abandon the thread
 2. Make a series of "challenges"
 3. Attempt to shift the burden of proof (again)

 5. Various combinations of the above
